                    NYU Winter Session in New York for Undergraduates    Winter session, or January Term , offers undergraduate students the chance to enroll in one course on the Washington Square campus to allow intensive study of the subject matter. NYU's policy is that students may take only one course during the winter term.    January Term courses enable students to earn academic credit (major, minor, or elective); to accelerate degree completion; and to concentrate on personal interests.    Please note: These courses are separate from fall and spring terms, and different financial aid and registration policies apply . Please see the NYU January Term webpage for complete information.    Graduate Courses In New York    Steinhardt offers several graduate courses on Washington Square in three-week intensives during January 2015. Please see Albert for exact program dates. These courses count toward Spring semester credit load and Spring tuition costs.    January 2015 Offerings:    Administration, Leadership, and Technology       Research Approaches and Techniques        Applied Psychology       Cross Cultural Counseling    Grief and Bereavement Counseling    HIV Prevention and Counseling: Psychoeducational Perspectives       Art and Art Professions       None for January 2015       Communicative Sciences and Disorders       Interdisciplinary Case-Based Dysphagia Management    Interdisciplinary Habilitation of Speaking Voice/Vocal Performance: Synergistic Remediation Effect    Language and Communication in Children with Autism Spectrum Disorders    Seminar in Speech Pathology: Augmentative Communication Devices       Humanities and Social Sciences in the Professions       None for January 2015       Media, Culture, and Communication       Visual Culture Methods       Music and Performing Arts Professions       Ethics in Drama Therapy    Interdisciplinary Habilitation of Speaking Voice/Vocal Performance: Synergistic Remediation Effect    Theater Aesthetics and Drama Therapy       Nutrition, Food Studies, and Public Health       Interdisciplinary Case-Based Management of Dysphagia Management    Professional Writing in Public Health       Occupational Therapy       Sensory Processing Challenges and Opportunities: Austism       Physical Therapy       None for January 2015        Teaching and Learning       Educating Children with Special Needs in Early Childhood Settings     Literacy Assessment       Students register on Albert; courses are found under Spring 2015 listings by department. Please consult your academic advisor on how courses can be allocated toward degree requirements.                    This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©        by New York University. All rights reserved.    Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development - 82 Washington Square East, New York, NY 10003

                        Winter Programs                                                          Interdisciplinary Habilitation of Speaking Voice/Vocal Performance: Synergistic Remediation Effect            Course Number: CSCD-GE.2136/MPAVP-GE.2175    Instructor: Celia Stewart    Points: 2    Course meets: 1/12 & 1/13 MoTu 12:30-4:15pm; 1/14 & 1/15 WedTh 1:30-4pm; 1/20 & 1/21 TuWed 1:30-4pm; 1/23/2015 Fri 4-6pm    Description: This course will focus on the collaborative interdisciplinary remediation of singers by vocologists (speech language pathologist & singing teachers), & otolaryngologists. Through master clinician demonstrations, student led discussions, & hands on voice training experience, student clinicians will work as a team to evaluate, develop, implement, & critique the effectiveness of the training/treatment. Students will use evidence based practice, discipline specific vocal exercises, & approaches to heighten efficiency of the vocal mechanism in order to reduce effort. Psychological aspects of voice use as well as body awareness will be discussed to aid in the promotion of sustainable production of voice in both speech & singing.    For more information regarding professors and meeting times, students can use Albert directly. The course can be found under both the Department of Communcative Sciences and Disorders and the Department of Music and Performing Arts Professions.                    This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©        by New York University. All rights reserved. Steinhardt LinkedIn        NYU Steinhardt RSS        NYU Steinhardt Instagram                                                   Winter Programs                                                                    NYU Winter Session in New York for Undergraduates    Winter session, or January Term , offers undergraduate students the chance to enroll in one course on the Washington Square campus to allow intensive study of the subject matter. NYU's policy is that students may take only one course during the winter term.    January Term courses enable students to earn academic credit (major, minor, or elective); to accelerate degree completion; and to concentrate on personal interests.    Please note: These courses are separate from fall and spring terms, and different financial aid and registration policies apply . Please see the NYU January Term webpage for complete information.    Graduate Courses In New York    Steinhardt offers several graduate courses on Washington Square in three-week intensives during January 2015. Please see Albert for exact program dates. These courses count toward Spring semester credit load and Spring tuition costs.    January 2015 Offerings:    Administration, Leadership, and Technology       Research Approaches and Techniques        Applied Psychology       Cross Cultural Counseling    Grief and Bereavement Counseling    HIV Prevention and Counseling: Psychoeducational Perspectives       Art and Art Professions       None for January 2015       Communicative Sciences and Disorders       Interdisciplinary Case-Based Dysphagia Management    Interdisciplinary Habilitation of Speaking Voice/Vocal Performance: Synergistic Remediation Effect    Language and Communication in Children with Autism Spectrum Disorders    Seminar in Speech Pathology: Augmentative Communication Devices       Humanities and Social Sciences in the Professions       None for January 2015       Media, Culture, and Communication       Visual Culture Methods       Music and Performing Arts Professions       Ethics in Drama Therapy    Interdisciplinary Habilitation of Speaking Voice/Vocal Performance: Synergistic Remediation Effect    Theater Aesthetics and Drama Therapy       Nutrition, Food Studies, and Public Health       Interdisciplinary Case-Based Management of Dysphagia Management    Professional Writing in Public Health       Occupational Therapy       Sensory Processing Challenges and Opportunities: Austism       Physical Therapy       None for January 2015        Teaching and Learning       Educating Children with Special Needs in Early Childhood Settings     Literacy Assessment       Students register on Albert; courses are found under Spring 2015 listings by department.
